p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, I present the third report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament.
PETITIONS
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
Mental Health

This petition of Concerned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the serious crisis existing in mental health care in rural and remote areas of Australia. Department of Health records show that between 2010 and 2017 the rate of suicide in rural and remote areas was almost two and a half times greater than that of major cities. In 2017 the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) counselled 24,500 patients suffering from depression. Dr Martin Laverty, CEO of RFDS stated, " We could double or triple that service tomorrow and still not touch the surface." The Senate Report into 'The Accessibility and Quality of Mental Health Services in Rural and Remote Australia' (2018) identified serious deficiencies in both areas. We are one of many families who have lost a loved one as a result of mental health illness. Before my nephew's death we realised that mental health services in country areas were totally inadequate. Specialist medical professionals' visits were irregular and did not provide the essential continuous care he required. Our only alternative was to seek treatment in expensive private clinics in Sydney. This is not a viable alternative for many people in rural areas.

We therefore ask the House to consider the development of a national rural mental health strategy ensuring: 1. Improved access to psychiatrists, psychologists and trained healthcare workers in rural communities. 2. Residential accommodation is provided in rural communities while patients receive support from these professionals.
from 2343 citizens (Petition No. PN0426)
Falun Gong

This petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Falun Gong is a peaceful meditation practice based on the principles of Truthfulness, Compassion and Tolerance. Falun Gong practitioners in China have been subjected to the most brutal and relentless persecution by the Chinese Communist regime since July 1999, causing thousands to lose their lives from illegal detention and systematic torture. Such conduct stands in blatant violation of all international human rights charters that the Chinese government has itself ratified. According to investigative reports published by human rights lawyer David Matas and former Canadian Secretary of State for the Asia Pacific; David Kilgour, tens of thousands of imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners have been subjected to forced organ harvesting for China's transplant market and lost their lives ( www.organharvestinvestigation.net ).
We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister to openly and forthrightly call for an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China.
from 16837 citizens (Petition No. PN0428)
Aged Care

From evidence that has arisen from the Royal commission into the Aged Care crisis it is undeniable that there has been serious breaches of human rights regarding psychotropic drugs. If these breaches can be made to the most vunerable the Ageing it is without a doubt that the same breaches are occurring in other systems that have been implemented for the protection of citizens in Australia such as the criminal justice system, disability services and the mental health sector. I believe that evidence shown to the Aged Care Royal Commission has clearly shown the use of psychotropic medicines as the major contributor to the vast problems in the sector. This issue should be treated as a separate issue outside of the Royal Commission as other sectors relevant should be given attention with respect to the serious nature of the issue. An inquiry would put into action the changes needed to facilitate the proper use of psychotropic drugs in these sectors with future alternatives and future spending portfolios around rehabilitation of the sector and it's health professionals in which there is clearly a lack of and also the lack of proper facilities for them to apply their wares.

We therefore ask the House to form an inquiry into the over use of psychotropic medicines and most importantly those prescribing them in Australia, not oly in Aged Care but in our criminal justice system, mental health systems and disability sectors.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. PN0430)
China: Organ Harvesting

This petition of local residents and business owners in the electorate of Flinders, draws to the attention of the House the recent final judgment and report from the independent China Tribunal chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC stating that forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one - and probably the main - source of organ supply.

We therefore ask the House to: 1) support a resolution condemning the forced organ harvesting of the Falun Gong people and other prisoners of conscience in China 2) to support an introduction of a bill to discourage Australian citizens from travelling to China for organ transplants until such time that there can be evidence that no organs have been taken by force against the will of the donor.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. PN0431)
Aged Care

From evidence that has arisen from the Royal Commission into the Aged care crisis it is undeniable that there has been serious breaches of human rights regarding psychotropic drugs. If these breaches can be made to the most vulnerable the Ageing it is without doubt that the same breaches are occurring in other systems that have been implemented for the protection of citizens in Australia such as the criminal justice system, disability services and the mental health sector. I believe that evidence shown to the Aged Care Royal Commission has clearly shown the use of psychotropic medicines as the major contributor to the vast problems in the sector. This issue should be treated as a separate issue outside of the Royal Commission as other sectors relevant should be given attention with respect to the serious nature of the issue. An inquiry would put into action the changes needed to facilitate the proper use of psychotropic drugs in these sectors with future alternatives and future spending portfolios around rehabilitation of the sector and it's health professionals in which there is clearly a lack of and also the lack of proper facilities for them to apply their wares.

We therefore ask the House to form an inquiry into the over use of psychotropic medicines and most importantly those prescribing them in Australia, not only in Aged Care but in our criminal justice system, mental health systems and disability sectors.
from 99 citizens (Petition No. EN0964)
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): I present the following 41 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Taxation
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your representations of 13 February 2017 originally directed to the then Treasurer, regarding a petition (EN0049) from the residents of Kangaroo Island regarding the Zone Tax Offset. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for response. The delay in response is regretted.

The Treasurer has requested that the Productivity Commission undertake a review into the ongoing form and function of remote area tax assistance, including the zone tax offset, to ensure it remains fair and contemporary. The review will commence in February 2019 and the Commission is due to report to Government within 12 months.

The Commission will undertake broad public consultation, including meeting directly with regional communities and inviting public submissions. Further information and the terms of reference can be found on the Commission's website at www.pc.gov.au/inquiries/current/zone-tax.

The Government welcomes community participation in the consultation process, and encourages members of the Kangaroo Island community to make submissions and engage in the Commission's consultation process. The Commission can be contacted via email at zonetax@pc.gov.au.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer the Hon. Stuart Robert MP
Venezuela
Dear Mr Vasta
Thank you for your letter of 20 June 2017 regarding the petition on the situation in Venezuela presented in the House on 19 June 2017 (Petition Number EN0180).

The Government has regularly expressed concern at increasing violence in Venezuela in both Canberra and Caracas, and will continue to encourage the Government of Venezuela and the Opposition to engage in meaningful dialogue to restore stability.

We believe that working collectively with other countries within multicultural fora, such as the United Nations Human Rights Committee, presents a good mechanism for Australia to influence the situation.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Julie Bishop MP
Nuclear Weapons Ban Treaty
Dear Mr Vasta
Thank you for your letter of 20 June 2017 conveying petition number EN0204, presented on 19 June 2017, regarding the nuclear weapons ban treaty.

Australia is committed to the goal of a world free of nuclear weapons. This goal must be pursued in an effective, determined and pragmatic way. Eliminating nuclear weapons is not a quick or easy task. It will take sustained, practical and incremental steps. The Australian Government has a consistent, considered position on a nuclear weapons `ban treaty'. A ban treaty would be ineffective in eliminating nuclear weapons. Proceeding with ban treaty negotiations without the participation of states possessing nuclear weapons, or without due regard to the international security environment, will not help to create the conditions for further major reductions in nuclear arsenals. Such a treaty risks undermining the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) and other treaties by creating ambiguity and confusion through parallel obligations, and by deepening divisions between nuclear and non-nuclear weapon states.

The NPT is one of the world's most universal treaties. It is the cornerstone of global nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament, and of global peace and security. The NPT already has a consensus-based roadmap for the elimination of nuclear weapons, as expressed in the 2010 NPT Action Plan. Australia's priority is to strengthen the NPT and to implement the Action Plan, as the agreed and most realistic means of achieving progress on nuclear disarmament.

Australia and Japan co-founded in 2010 the Non Proliferation and Disarmament Initiative, a cross-regional group of 12 countries: Australia, Canada, Chile, Germany, Japan, Mexico, the Netherlands, Nigeria, the Philippines, Poland, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates. Through this group and other dedicated efforts, Australia continues to take forward the NPT Action Plan.

Consistent with the NPT Action Plan, the Australian Government promotes and is active in other initiatives to advance nuclear disarmament. We have long promoted the global norm against nuclear testing established under the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT). To advocate universalisation and entry-into-force of the CTBT, I co-chaired a 'Friends of the CTBT' event involving the UN Secretary-General and 80 countries, 40 of these at ministerial level, in New York in September 2016.

Australia is maintaining policy and technical work on a future Fissile Material Cut-Off Treaty (FMCT), and working with both nuclear weapon states and non-nuclear weapon states to develop technical tools capable of verifying nuclear disarmament. In 2016 we co-sponsored a UN General Assembly resolution which established a Group of Government Experts to progress work on disarmament verification.
Australia will continue to pursue practical steps and the political will needed to bring about a world without nuclear weapons.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Julie Bishop MP
Nuclear Weapons Ban Treaty

2

I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Julie Bishop MP
Taxation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 August 2018 to the then Treasurer, the Hon Scott Morrison MP. regarding petition number EN0625 to replace Australia's current personal and company income tax rates with a flat tax rate. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. The delay in response is regretted.

Australia relies heavily on individual and corporate income tax as a source of revenue. Although there is scope to remove unnecessary complexity within the tax system, there is a trade-off between simplicity and fairness. Simple taxes (such as a system with a flat tax) are easy to administer and understand but they do not take into account the actual economic position of different taxpayers.

While replacing Australia's progressive tax system with a flat rate would benefit some taxpayers, others, particularly those on low incomes, would be worse off Progressive tax rates reflect the principle of vertical equity: that each person should contribute to the cost of government services according to their ability to pay. A tax is progressive if the ratio of tax to income rises when moving up the income scale. That is, people with higher taxable incomes pay more tax as a proportion of their income than those on lower incomes.

The current income tax system features a number of concessions targeted at low- and middle-income earners. An individual taxpayer, for example, does not currently pay any income tax or the Medicare levy if their taxable income is $20,542 or lower. A flat tax rate would increase the income tax burden for all people who are below this threshold level, as well as for many people above it, because the rate of such a flat tax would have to be high. Consequently, a flat tax rate that raised the same amount of revenue as the current progressive tax system would see high-income earners paying less tax and low‑income earners paying more tax. Most Australians would consider this an inequitable outcome, as would the Government.

Nor does the Government support increasing the tax free threshold for all individuals in line with the average annual wage. In line with the principle of vertical equity, the Government targets assistance to low income individuals and withdraws this assistance as their incomes increase.

Under the general deduction provisions of income tax law, tax deductions arc allowed for losses and outgoings to the extent they are incurred in gaining or producing assessable income, or are necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing income. A flat tax imposed on gross income with no deductions would treat many taxpayers harshly. For example, taxpayers running businesses would be unable to deduct any expenses incurred in earning their income, such as wages of employees, goods purchased from suppliers, costs of plant and equipment used in the business, or interest costs incurred in borrowing to fund the business.

The Government is committed to maintaining a progressive personal income tax system. Progressivity has been a longstanding feature of the Australian taxation system and reflects the preferences of the Australian people over a long period of time under many different governments. This is a core feature of Australia's tax and transfer system. The Government considers that this is the appropriate system for Australia.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer the Hon. Stuart Robert MP
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter dated 15 October 2018 concerning National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) pricing for Behavioural Clinicians.
The ND1S Provider Registration Guide to Suitability provides information to assist
providers to understand their quality, safeguards and compliance obligations as registered providers of supports funded through the NDIS.

To minimise risk, enhance outcomes and maximise the social and economic participation of people with disability, certain supports are required to be provided by people with specific qualifications and experience. The professions listed in the NDIS Provider Registration Guide to Suitability reflect the expectations agreed upon by the Commonwealth, National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) and jurisdictions where the arrangements will apply during transition to full Scheme.

Professions in the NDIS Provider Registration Guide to Suitability provide services and supports that arc appropriate for the ND1S to fund. These supports and services are considered reasonable and necessary (appropriate to the disability related goals of an individual NDIS participant) able to increase social and economic participation and are likely to be effective and beneficial to the participant.

The Early Childhood Early Intervention (ECEI) approach supports children aged zero to six years, including children with Autism Spectrum Disorder, and their families and carers, to access early childhood intervention services to support lifelong functional outcomes. The ECEI approach aims to ensure parents and primary caregivers can provide experiences and opportunities that help children gain and use the functional skills they need to participate meaningfully throughout their lives. Families of children who are participants of the NDIS are supported to apply their choice and control when engaging providers for the delivery of the reasonable and necessary supports in their child's plan.

Regarding registration of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA) professionals under the ND1S, although ABA qualification is internationally recognised, ABA professionals in Australia are not yet recognised as Allied Health Providers. As such, they are unable to obtain Medicare or Private Health Insurance provider numbers.

The NDIS recognises a broad range of clinical expertise in behaviour management across the medical and allied health professions and provides reasonable and necessary supports to participants, so they can choose the appropriate supports to help them achieve their goals.
Thank you for raising this matter with me. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services the Hon. Paul Fletcher
Parliamentarians' Entitlements
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 19 February 2019 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition (number EN0739) presented in the House of Representatives regarding remuneration and work related expenses for Members of Parliament. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.
As you would be aware, remuneration arrangements for Members of Parliament are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal which is independent from the Commonwealth Government.

The Government has tightened the work expenses available to current and former Parliamentarians through its reforms to the parliamentary expenses framework. On 1 January 2018, the Parliamentary Business Resources Act 2017 and Regulations came into effect which streamline parliamentarians' work expenses, better define when parliamentarians can claim expenses and make politicians more accountable for their use of taxpayers' dollars.

These are the biggest reforms to the management of parliamentarians' expenses in more than a generation and implements the recommendations of the February 2016 review, An Independent Parliamentary Entitlements System, co-chaired by Mr John Conde AO and Mr David Tune AO PSM. The Government agreed to all recommendations of the
Conde/Tune review.
One of the recommendations was to establish the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority (IPEA) which commenced as a statutory authority on 1 July 2017. IPEA's core functions are to:
audit and report on parliamentarians' work expenses;
provide clear and consistent guidance to parliamentarians; and
monitor and administer claims for travel expenses and allowances.
Accordingly, the Government considers that current arrangements for determining remuneration and work related expenses for Members of Parliament are appropriate.
The Prime Minister appreciates you bringing this petition to his attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister the Hon. Steve Irons MP

subdebateinfo.title: McInnes, Mr Gavin, Robinson, Mr Tommy

p.span: McInnes, Mr Gavin
Robinson, Mr Tommy
Dear Committee Secretary

I refer to correspondence of 18 February 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, regarding petition EN0764 concerning Mr Tommy Robinson and Mr Gavin McInnes' proposed visit to Australia. The Minister appreciates the time you have taken to bring this matter to his attention and has asked that I reply on his behalf. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Due to privacy legislation, I cannot comment on the particulars of their cases. However, I am able to provide information on the provisions of the character test under section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act).

The Department takes very seriously its role in protecting the community and all non-citizens wishing to enter Australia must meet the legislated visa requirements, including character requirements set out in the Act. A non-citizen may fail the character test for a number of reasons, including but not limited to if they have a substantial criminal record or engage in criminal conduct, or if it is assessed that they may vilify, incite discord, or represent a danger to the Australian community or a segment of the Australian community. All visitors to Australia are expected to respect, and behave in accordance with, Australian laws.

There are strong provisions in the Act that allow the Department of Home Affairs to refuse or cancel a visa, where a person is found not to be of good character. Once a visa is granted, the holder must continue to meet the character requirements as well as the conditions imposed on their visa. If they breach visa conditions or engage in criminal activity or conduct of concern, their visa may be considered for cancellation.
Further information on the character provisions of the Act can be found on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our-requirements/character.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
from Justine Jones, Assistant Secretary, Character and Cancellation Branch, Department of Home Affairs
Okonma, Mr Tyler Gregory
Dear Committee Secretary

I refer to correspondence of 18 February 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon David Coleman MP, regarding petition EN0779 concerning Mr Tyler Gregory Okonma. The Minister appreciates the time you have taken to bring this matter to his attention and has asked that I reply on his behalf. I apologise for the delay in responding.
I note separate correspondence also dated 18 February 2019, referring petition EN0784, also in relation to Mr Okonma.
Due to privacy legislation, I cannot comment on the particulars of this case. However,
I am able to provide information on the provisions of the character test under section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act).

The Department of Home Affairs takes its role very seriously in protecting the community and all non-citizens wishing to enter Australia must meet the legislated visa requirements, including character requirements set out in the Act. A non-citizen may fail the character test for a number of reasons, including where they have a substantial criminal record or if it is assessed that they may vilify, incite discord, or represent a danger to the Australian community.

Where a decision maker reasonably suspects that a person does not pass the character test, further consideration is undertaken to assess the specific circumstances of the case. Further information on the character provisions of the Act can be found on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our­requirements/character.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
from Nigel Muir, Acting Assistant Secretary, Immigration and Settlement Services Group, Department of Home Affairs
Okonma, Mr Tyler Gregory

from Nigel Muir, Acting Assistant Secretary, Immigration and Settlement Services Group, Department of Home Affairs
New Zealand Citizens
Dear Committee Secretary

I refer to correspondence of 18 February 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon David Coleman MP, regarding petition EN0788, which requests that the Australian Government ban the deportation of permanent residents who have children born in Australia, specifically New Zealand citizens. The Minister appreciates the time you have taken to bring this matter to his attention and has asked that I reply on his behalf. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Department of Home Affairs takes seriously its responsibility to protect the Australian community from non-citizens who engage in criminal conduct or behaviour of concern. This is why there are strong provisions in the Migration Act 1958 to refuse or cancel a non-citizen's visa if they have engaged in such conduct. These provisions are an important means of protecting the Australian community from non-citizens who could present a character, integrity or security risk.

I note the petition's concerns in relation to the cancellation of Australian permanent resident visas for New Zealand citizens who have children born in Australia. I assure you that the Department takes seriously its international legal obligations in all migration decision making, especially those under the 1989 United Nations Convention relating to the Rights of the Child.

When considering whether to refuse an application, or cancel the visa, of a non-citizen under the character framework, departmental delegates and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal must consider a wide range of primary or other factors contained within a binding Ministerial Direction. This direction provides that a primary factor is the consideration of the best interests of minor children in Australia effected by the decision.

The direction requires delegates to determine whether or not the cancellation is in the best interests of the child by considering the nature and duration of the relationship, the impact of the person's criminal conduct on the minor, the likely effect that separation would have and any known views of the minor where appropriate.

While the rights relating to family and children are considerably weighted against cancellation or refusal, there will be circumstances where this will be outweighed by the risk to the Australian community due to the seriousness of the person's criminal record, past behaviour or associations. In such an instance, the Department will remain committed to protecting the Australian community from the risk of harm from foreign nationals.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
From Andrew McGrath, Acting Assistant Secretary, Compliance and Community Protection Policy Branch, Immigration and Community Protection Policy Division, Department of Home Affairs
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Brien

I refer to correspondence of 18 February 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, concerning petition EN0808. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.

The success of Australia's border protection policies has also enabled the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing the global humanitarian crisis and increase our Humanitarian Programme annual quota to 18,750 places, which represents the largest ongoing program in over 30 years.

No individual under regional processing arrangements in Nauru or Papua New Guinea (PNG) is detained. All individuals reside in open living arrangements in the community, and are free to move around without restriction.

Individuals under regional processing arrangements receive a range of services to support their stay in Nauru or PNG, including health and welfare, accommodation (rent and utility free), education and employment opportunities.

Medical services are provided by a range of healthcare professionals, including general practitioners, psychiatrists, counsellors, and mental health nurses who provide clinical assessment and treatment.

Where specialist medical treatment is not available in a regional processing country, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfers to a third country, including Australia, for assessment or treatment.

Under regional processing arrangements, refugees have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled. People found to be refugees by the Government of PNG can settle in PNG. People found to be refugees by the Government of Nauru can stay in Nauru for 20 years. People in either country can express an interest in United States resettlement, seek assisted voluntary return or move to a country they have the right to reside in.

Australia appreciates the offer from the New Zealand Government to resettle refugees, however we are focused on completing the larger arrangement with the US. Australia's border protection policies have removed the incentive for people to join dangerous and illegal people smuggling ventures to Australia. The Australian Government remains mindful of not undoing efforts to combat people smuggling.

Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol. Regional processing arrangements provide illegal maritime arrivals an opportunity to have their protection claims assessed, and for those found to be refugees, resettlement in a third country, without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Peter Dutton MP
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 February 2019 concerning petition number EN0837, which was presented in the House of Representatives, concerning the request of asylum for Ms Rahaf Mohammed AI-Qunun of Saudi Arabia.
Australia welcomes the news that Ms Al-Qunun has been offered a place in Canada's humanitarian programme.

The safety of Ms Al-Qunun has always been the Australian Government's primary concern, and we worked with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and international partners to ensure her claim was assessed appropriately.
At the time of the UNHCR's referral to Canada on 11 January 2019, the assessment of Ms Al-Qunun's case by Australian officials was progressing.
Australia has one of the most generous humanitarian programmes in the world, and all applications are considered in accordance with Australian law and procedures.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs the Hon. David Coleman MP
Environment
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019 regarding Petition number EN0844. I regret the delay in responding.

1 understand your concerns about water management in the Murray-Darling Basin. The Murray-Darling Basin Plan is an adaptive management framework that provides a stable basis for balancing the needs of the environment, farmers and community for the long-term. It is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to restore our important river systems to a healthy and sustainable level to the benefit of the environment as well as the communities and industries that rely on them. It does this by establishing and enforcing sustainable diversion limits on water that may be taken from Basin water resources to meet economic, social and environmental outcomes. To support Basin Plan implementation, the Australian Government is providing $3.3 billion to the Sustainable Diversion Limit adjustment mechanism and the Northern Basin Review.

The Basin Plan ensures that the use of water for production and the environment is sustainable. It seeks to achieve this balance without the need for compulsory acquisition, balancing the use of water across the system and supporting the health of Basin as a whole.

Australian communities have made their concerns about the fish deaths in the lower Darling River and water availability in the Basin very clear. The fish deaths are a terrible reminder of the effects drought and limited water flows can have on the environment and rural communities. The drought has been particularly harsh on the Darling River system, where there have been little to no inflows and unfortunately, there is still a risk of further fish deaths if there are not significant flows within the system. To help improve water flows, the Commonwealth Environmental Water Holder released 27 to 36 GL environmental water into a number of northern rivers from April to June 2019 to support native fish and improve water quality. As at 10 July 2019, these flows have travelled 1,200 km of the river, reaching and filling the Walgett and Brewarrina weir pools and improving dissolved oxygen in the Barwon River. The flow led to water flowing over the Walgett weir for the first time since July 2018.

Early this year the government appointed an independent panel, chaired by Professor Rob Vertessy, to assess the fish deaths in the lower Darling. The panel's report confirmed that low dissolved oxygen levels caused by a range of factors including the breakdown of water layers in the river, decomposition of organic matter, algal blooms and the high temperatures followed by cooler periods contributed to the fish deaths. The report is available at mdba.gov.au/publications/mdba-reports/independent-panel-assess-fish-deaths-lower-darling

2
With regard to moving water from the Ord River in Western Australia, you will be pleased to know that the government is getting on with the job of building new water infrastructure to meet regional Australia's needs. It is providing more than $3.3 billion in funding, through the

$1.3 billion National Water Infrastructure Development Fund and the $2 billion National Water Infrastructure Loan Facility. This funding will go towards identifying and building dams, weirs and pipelines that will deliver secure and affordable water for rural and regional Australia. To date, the government has committed more than $990 million to fund the construction of 21 water projects with a total construction value of more than $1.98 billion.

The government is also establishing the National Water Grid Authority (the Authority). The Authority will deliver on the government's election commitment to invest $100 million to bring together world-best science and identify opportunities to increase water supply and reliability. The Australian Government is committed to the sustainable development of Australia's water resources and integrating our water infrastructure to support the growth of regional Australia and meet the demands of a growing population. The new Authority and major water infrastructure development is the responsibility of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, the Hon. Michael McCormack MP.
Thank you for bringing these matters to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management the Hon. David Littleproud MP
Australian Embassies
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 5 April 2019 regarding petition number EN0847 asking the House to put forward a motion to close smaller Australian Embassies and Consulates.

Australia's network of overseas posts, including Embassies, High Commissions and Consulates, underpin the Australian Government's ability to protect and promote Australia's interests overseas. They build and maintain key relationships, promote strong commercial, security and political outcomes, and help the large number of Australians who travel overseas each year or live permanently abroad.
The Australian Government provides consular services through our network of overseas posts, managing on any given day around 1,500 active cases involving Australians in difficulty overseas.
The Government reviews regularly the scope and distribution of Australia's network of overseas posts, including to ensure they deliver value-for-money.
Thank you for bringing this issue to the attention of the Government.

from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Women Senator theHon. Marise Payne
Epilepsy
Dear MrsWicks

I refer to the letter to you from the Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning petition EN0849 that was presented by the Member for Cowan, the Hon Dr Anne Aly MP, regarding more funding and assistance for people with epilepsy in Western Australia, as well as Australia wide. The request for epilepsy to be classified as a disability within legislation was referred to me.

Programs and services generally have their own eligibility criteria for providing support to people with epilepsy, including the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) and Disability Support Pension (DSP). The assistance or supports available in a particular situation are generally based on the functional capacity of the individual seeking assistance, rather than their particular condition.
More information on the NDIS and DSP, including how to claim, can be found at www.NDIS.gov.au and www.humanservices.gov.au.

from the Minister for Families and Social Services Senator the Hon. Anne Ruston
National Firearms Agreement
Dear Mr O'Brien

I refer to correspondence of 5 April 2019 from the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP,concerning petition EN0852 requesting the repeal of the National Firearms Agreement. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The regulation of firearms in Australia is shared between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. The Commonwealth has responsibility for the import and export of firearms, while the states and territories are responsible for the licensing of firearm owners and the registration, possession and use of firearms.

The national approach to the regulation of firearms is set out in the National Firearms Agreement. The National Firearms Agreement was originally signed in 1996 following the Port Arthur massacre and was recently updated in response to a recommendation of the Joint Commonwealth-NSW Martin Place Siege Review. The National Firearms Agreement is a commitment by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments to a minimum set of standards for the regulation of firearms, including that personal protection is not a genuine reason for the possession of a firearm.

The Agreement achieves the balance of protecting the rights of the Australian community to live safely and securely with the interests of those with a genuine reason and need to access firearms. The Australian Government is committed to supporting and upholding the National Firearms Agreement.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs the Hon. Peter Dutton MP
Work for the Dole
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 10 April 2019 to the former Minister for Jobs and Industrial Relations, the Hon Kelly O'Dwyer, regarding Petition Number EN0855—Work for the Dole Program. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities as Minister for Employment, Skills, Small and Family Business, your letter was referred to me for reply.

The Australian Government believes that all Australians of working age who are capable of working should be in a job, Work for the Dole provides work-like experiences to help participants who have been unemployed for 12 months or more to gain skills, experience, and confidence to move from welfare to work while giving back to the local community.

Work for the Dole is an important part of the Government's activation policy and it works. Work for the Dole is one of several activity options available for job seekers to meet their mutual obligation requirements.

The Department of Employment, Skills, Small and Family Business undertakes regular surveys of Work for the Dole participants, with 75 per cent of participants reporting an increased desire to find a job, 74 per cent reporting an improved ability to work with others, and 68 per cent reporting improved work-related skills.

While Work for the Dole is not a job-matching program, around 37 per cent of participants leave the program due to getting a job, and between 25 and 30 per cent of participants are in a job three months after participating.

The suggestion that Work for the Dole is an exploitative program is not true. Work for the Dole activities cannot involve the same tasks that would normally be completed by a paid worker and cannot cause a reduction in the hours usually worked by a paid worker.

The majority of Work for the Dole host organisations are not for profit or community organisations. Work for the Dole activities help host organisations make positive contributions to local communities and these communities benefit from a range of improvements due to these activities.

In regard to the concerns raised around the handling of job seeker information, employment providers have obligations under the Privacy Act 1988 to ensure that personal information (including sensitive information) is collected, held, used and disclosed in accordance with that Act. Schedule 1 of the Privacy Act sets out thirteen Australian Privacy Principles, which govern the ways in which personal information must be managed.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment, Skills, Small and Family Business Senator the Hon. Michaelia Cash
Tobacco
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your personal representation of 5 April 2019 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN0856 - House to reduce the tax on tobacco and increase the tax on alcohol. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

Despite the recent decline in the incidence of smoking, it remains one of the leading preventable causes of death and disease in Australia, killing more than 15,000 Australians each year. The social costs of smoking (including the health costs) are estimated at $31.5 billion each year. Annually, over 750,000 hospital bed days are attributable to tobacco related diseases.

The US Surgeon General has stated in a report (The Health Consequences of Smoking -50 Years of Progress) that increasing the cost of cigarettes 'is one of the most powerful interventions we can make to prevent smoking and reduce prevalence'.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer the Hon. Michael Sukkar MP
Health
Dear Chair

I refer to the letter of 5 April 2019 from the former Chair, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, concerning petition EN0866 regarding the reinstatement of a Q Fever Management Program. I regret the delay in responding.

Q fever is a potentially serious disease and vaccination remains the best form of protection. The Australian Government subsidises Q fever vaccine production and supply to the Australian market through substantial funding to the only global manufacturer, Seqirus Australia Pty Ltd (Seqirus). This funding ensures those at a high risk of Q fever have access to a vaccine. Australia is the only country in the world that routinely uses the Q fever vaccine as part of its prevention efforts. The Australian Government provides approximately $42 million per year to Seqirus to ensure supply of Q fever vaccine, antivenoms and pandemic influenza vaccine.

Current funding arrangements will ensure all Australians have access to the Q fever skin test and vaccine until 2024. Without this government support, Seqirus would not produce these products, as they are not commercially viable due to the low quantities purchased.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of vaccination and provides free vaccines to eligible cohorts through the National Immunisation Program (NIP). Under the National Health Act 1953, the Government cannot consider funding a vaccine on the NIP unless it has been recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). To date, the PBAC has not received a submission for Q-Vax from Seqirus.

As a commercial entity, Seqirus would need to consider a number of clinical, financial and supply factors in making an application to the PBAC for listing Q-Vax on the NIP or the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Pharmaceutical companies are private businesses that make their own decisions about the pricing of their medicines and whether they will market them exclusively on the private market or apply for subsidisation through the PBS or the NIP.

My Department takes Q fever disease seriously with the incidence and prevalence of Q fever closely monitored at the state/territory and national levels. Q fever is a nationally notifiable disease as part of Australia's National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System.
The Communicable Diseases Network Australia released National Guidelines for Q fever in November 2018. These Guidelines ensure consistent guidance in responding to a notifiable disease event.

I am confident that my Department is effectively monitoring Q fever through the national notification of cases of the disease. Should Seqirus make an application to the PBAC in seeking to list Q-Vax on the PBS and the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of this, the Government will list the medicine as a matter of priority.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service and Cabinet the Hon. Greg Hunt MP
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Brien

I refer to correspondence of 4 April 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, concerning petition number EN0867. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Australian Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.

The success of Australia's border protection policies has also enabled the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing the global humanitarian crisis and increase our Humanitarian Program annual quota to 18,750 places, which represents the largest ongoing program in over 30 years.

The health and welfare of individuals in regional processing countries is of paramount importance to the governments of Australia, Nauru and Papua New Guinea (PNG). Individuals receive a range of services to support their stay in Nauru or PNG, including health and welfare, accommodation (rent and utility free), education and employment opportunities.

No individual under regional processing arrangements in Nauru or PNG is detained. All individuals reside in open living arrangements in the community, and are free to move around without restriction. Regional processing arrangements maintain the dignity and human rights of people without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.

Individuals under regional processing have access to quality health care. Medical services are provided by a range of healthcare professionals, including general practitioners, psychiatrists, counsellors, and mental health nurses who provide clinical assessment and treatment.
Where specialist medical treatment is not available in a regional processing country, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfers to a third country, including Australia, for treatment,

Australia continues to support the Governments of Nauru and PNG to reduce the residual regional processing caseload through resettlement, returns and removals. Under current regional processing arrangements, refugees have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled.

People found to be refugees by the Government of PNG can settle in PNG. People found to be refugees by the Government of Nauru can stay in Nauru for 20 years. People in either country can seek assisted voluntary return or move to a country they have the right to reside in. In addition to this, a one-off arrangement with the United States to support the resettlement of refugees from PNG and Nauru is in place and is progressing.

Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol. Regional processing arrangements provide asylum seekers an opportunity to have their protection claims assessed, and for those found to be refugees to resettle in a third country, without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs the Hon. Peter Dutton MP
Great Barrier Reef
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence concerning petition number EN0880.

On 23 January 2019, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority granted Marine Park and sea dumping permits to North Queensland Bulk Ports Corporation following a 60 day community consultation period and environmental impact assessment process. Alternatives to at-sea disposal were considered during the comprehensive assessment process.
The dredged material will not be disposed of on coral reefs. Media reports earlier this year, about one million tonnes of material to be dumped on coral reefs, are inaccurate and untrue.

The ten year permits allow a total of up to 756,553 cubic metres of maintenance dredge material to be moved from the port and disposed of at a nearby location. A further 200,000 cubic metres of maintenance dredge material can be moved in response to extreme weather events such as cyclones.

The dredging will occur over separate campaigns every three to five years with strict permit conditions to protect the environment, including a requirement for sediment testing in accordance with the National Assessment Guidelines for Dredging 2009 prior to each dredge campaign over the permit term, Disposal is permitted in an existing disposal site within the Marine Park and modelling shows that sediment plumes will remain within natural levels for the Hay Point area.
The permits, assessment reports, Statement of Reasons and associated documentation is available at: gbrmpa.gov.au/about-us/consultation/consultation-completed.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment the Hon. Sussan Ley MP
Icke, Mr David
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 29 July 2019, regarding petition EN0885 concerning Mr David Icke. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
Due to privacy legislation, I cannot comment on the particulars of Mr Icke's case. However, I am able to provide information on the provisions of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act).

There are provisions in the Act that allow the Department of Home Affairs or the Minister to cancel the visas of non-citizens upon a range of grounds. Among other reasons, a visa may be cancelled where a non-citizen is a risk to the health, safety or good order of the Australian community, or has provided incorrect information.

A visa may be cancelled without natural justice where a non-citizen is offshore. Where a non-citizen's visa is cancelled offshore without natural justice, it is open to the non-citizen to seek revocation of the cancellation decision and provide information as to why their visa should be reinstated.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs the Hon. David Coleman
Goods and Services Tax
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 29 July 2019, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding Petition Number EN0888 - GST and fuel excise. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

Excise and customs duty are levied on producers and importers of fuels in Australia, who may then pass this on to consumers as a business cost in the form of higher prices. As GST is payable on the full purchase price of the fuel, which may reflect any taxes and other business costs, the Australian Government does not consider the GST to be a tax on a tax.

Indexation was reintroduced in 2014 in order to ensure that fuel tax revenues are not eroded over time by inflation. This has been a long standing feature of the excise system for most excisable goods, removing it would likely lead to calls for similar freezes across the excise system, such as alcohol and tobacco.

Fuel prices are influenced by many factors, including overseas and local market forces. Key factors include changes in international benchmark prices, the value of the Australian dollar, levels of competition in different areas and pricing decisions by wholesalers and retailers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission monitors retail fuel prices on a daily basis and where it sees issues of concern, it investigates. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer the Hon. Michael Sukkar MP
Lupus
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 29 July 2019 concerning petition EN0892 that was presented in the House of Representatives regarding more funding and assistance for people with lupus.
The Australian Government is committed to addressing the impact that chronic conditions, including lupus, have on the Australian community.
As you may be aware, lupus is closely associated with arthritis, due to joint pain and swelling being the most common symptom of the condition.

To support those affected by arthritis and associated conditions, such as lupus, the Government has funded Arthritis Australia to develop the National Strategic Action Plan for Arthritis (the Action Plan). The Action Plan is a nationally coordinated effort which focuses on actions to reduce the burden of disease for the people living with arthritis and associated conditions.

The petitioners may wish to raise their issues with Arthritis Australia or Lupus Australia to clarify the broader sector view, ascertain where work may already be planned or underway and to gauge whether the organisations would have an interest in submitting proposals to Government on any or all of the matters outlined in the petition.

Arthritis Australia can be contacted on (02) 9518 4441 or via the organisation's website at www.arthritisaustralia.com.au. Lupus Australia can be contacted on 1800 802 088 or via its website at www.lupusnsw.org.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service and Cabinet the Hon. Greg Hunt MP

The Liberal National Government has a comprehensive set of policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase energy efficiency and fast track the development and uptake of clean energy.
