Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter of 29 July 2019 seeking a response to a petition that was recently presented in the House of Representatives concerning the superannuation arrangements for parliamentarians (petition number EN0901).

Like all workers, parliamentarians receive superannuation to provide for their retirement. Under the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 pensions are only payable in respect of parliamentarians who entered the Parliament before 9 October 2004. This scheme provides pensions to retired parliamentarians who have served at least three terms in Parliament. The scheme requires mandatory contributions from the parliamentarian's after-tax salary, starting at 11.5% of the parliamentary allowance.

Parliamentarians who entered the Parliament after 9 October 2004, which constitutes more than 90 per cent of Federal Parliamentarians, are not entitled to a pension on retirement. Instead these parliamentarians are members of superannuation schemes that are common throughout the community. Under these schemes, the superannuation benefit is payable as a lump sum, consisting of accumulated contributions and earnings. Access to these benefits is subject to the same conditions that apply to the broader community.
Kind regards
from the Minister for Finance Senator the Hon. Mathias Cormann
Elections
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter dated 29 July 2019, referring petition number EN0906 to me as the Minister responsible for electoral policy. The petition requests the removal of the requirement for candidates in federal elections to pay a nomination deposit, to allow all Australians an opportunity to run in federal elections. I do not support the petition's request for the reasons outlined below.

The Parliament has recently affirmed the concept of a nomination deposit is valid. On 8 March 2019, the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Modernisation and Other Measures) Act 2019 made important reforms to candidate nominations. This included increasing the deposit for nomination of the House of Representatives from $1,000 to $2,000, to match that of the Senate. This increase ensured parity in cost for nominees in both houses of Parliament, whilst maintaining that the amount is not so high as to constitute a barrier to ordinary individuals participating in elections.

The deposit for a candidate in both a House of Representatives and Senate election will be returned, if the candidate is elected or the candidate's sum of first preference votes is at least four per cent of the total number of formal first preference votes cast for all candidates in the relevant election. Where a candidate's name is included in a Senate group ballot, the nomination deposit will be returned if the sum of the first preference votes received by all the candidates in the group is at least four per cent of the total number of formal first preference votes cast in the relevant state or territory.

The requirement for a nomination deposit does not infringe on the right of any eligible Australian to potentially represent the Australian people in Parliament. The nomination deposit is necessary to strike a balance between allowing all eligible Australians the opportunity to participate in elections while also establishing a reasonable threshold to reflect the seriousness of pursuing an elected office.
For these reasons, I do not support the petition's request. Thank you for bringing the concerns referred the petition to my attention.
Kind regards
from the Minister for Finance Senator the Hon. Mathias Cormann
Cost of Living
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 29 July 2019, on behalf of the Petitions Committee concerning petition EN0908 to increase wages.

Recent wages growth continues to show improving results. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Wage Price Index increased by 2.3 per cent over the year to the June quarter 2019, up from the 2.1 per cent increase at the same time last year. Wages growth also continues to outpace increases in the cost of living, with the increase in the Consumer Price Index being 1.6 per cent over the year to the June quarter 2019.

The independent Fair Work Commission is responsible for setting minimum wages, not the Government. In its most recent decision, the Commission increased wages for up to 2.2 million award reliant employees by 3.0 per cent from I July 2019. This follows previous increases of 3.5 per cent in 2018 and 3.3 per cent in 2017. The net result of these increases is Australia now benefits from the highest minimum wage in the world, as measured by the OECD.

To support wages growth, the Government is continuing to set the right conditions for a strong economy and record jobs growth. Under this Government, the labour market has strengthened considerably, with more than 1.4 million jobs created since the Coalition came to office. The Government will continue to build on this proud record by creating a further 1.25 million jobs over the next five years.

This Government remains committed to improving the living standards of Australians, allowing workers to keep more of what they earn and boosting their disposable income through the Government's personal income tax relief.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention, and I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations the Hon. Christian Porter MP
Syria: Attacks
Dear Mr Vasta MP
Thank you for your letter of 29 May 2017 regarding petition number PN0060.

Australia has consistently condemned the egregious abuses committed by Daesh in Syria and Iraq. In particular, Daesh's horrific persecution of religious, ethnic and other minority groups, including Yazidis and Christians, may amount to war crimes and crimes against humanity. We regularly raise issues of minority rights in UN fora and directly with governments in the region. In February 2017, I announced that Australia would contribute $150,000 towards a UN-sponsored accountability mechanism to investigate international crimes in Syria.

The crime of genocide is set out in the 1948 Genocide Convention and the 1998 Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. Australia is a party to both these conventions. In order to establish the crime of genocide has occurred, a number of elements must be met. This is an assessment to be made against specific facts which is a technical legal process. Australia is committed to ensuring that international law is upheld.

Importantly, Australia has been an active member of the Global Counter-ISIL Coalition since its inception, making a major military contribution and working to counter Daesh financing, ideology and recruitment. We have also committed $613 million in humanitarian assistance in response to the Iraq and Syria crises. We are resettling 12,000 Syrian and Iraqi refugees in addition to our regular intake, with a focus on vulnerable people and persecuted minorities.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Julie Bishop MP
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Brien,

I refer to correspondence of 13 August 2018 from the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, to the Hon Peter Dutton MP, former Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, regarding petition PN0090. This correspondence has been forwarded to the Hon David Coleman MP, Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, as the matter falls within his portfolio responsibilities. The Minister has asked that I respond to you, as the new Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, on his behalf. 1 apologise for the delay in responding.
1. With regard to the request to cease mandatory detention:

The Australian Government considers immigration detention an essential component of effective border control. Immigration detention of unlawful non-citizens is administrative, not punitive and may be used while determining whether to permit a valid application for a visa, receiving and determining such an application or implementing a removal from Australia.

Since 2008, the Australian Government policy has been to detain unlawful non-citizens in immigration detention centres only as a last resort and for the shortest practicable time. Most unlawful non-citizens are managed in the community through the grant of a bridging visa while they resolve their immigration status. Unlawful non-citizens who meet the following risk factors may not be granted a bridging visa and are hence managed in immigration detention:
All illegal arrivals—until the health, identity and security risks which they present to the Australian community are resolved;
Unlawful non-citizens who present unacceptable risks to the community, including persons with adverse security assessments; and
Unlawful non-citizens who have repeatedly refused to comply with their visa conditions.
2. With regard to the request to close the camps on Nauru and Manus Island:

To uphold the integrity of the humanitarian program while ensuring that people do not risk their lives by undertaking the dangerous journey to Australia on boats illegally operated by people smugglers, the Australian Government has implemented several disruption and deterrence measures.

Illegal Maritime Arrivals are liable for transfer to a regional processing country where their claims for protection are assessed. Australia supports the Governments of Papua New Guinea (PNG) and Nauru to provide health and welfare services and durable outcomes to persons transferred under regional processing arrangements.

The PNG Government closed the Manus Regional Processing Centre on 31 October 2017. All residents were transferred to alternative accommodation sites by the PNG Government, who is responsible for the management of these accommodation sites.

No individual under regional processing arrangements in PNG and Nauru is detained. All individuals reside in open living arrangements in the community, and are free to move around without restriction.

Under regional processing arrangements, refugees have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled. People found to be refugees by the PNG Government can settle in PNG. People found to be refugees by the Government of Nauru can stay in Nauru for 20 years. People in both countries can express an interest in United States resettlement, seek assisted voluntary return or move to a country in which they have the right to reside.

People claiming asylum who are found not to be owed protection as set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol and other international human rights conventions to which Australia is a party can access support to return to their home country.
3. With regard to the request to process all claims for asylum in Australia in a fair and timely manner

The Australian Government is committed to assessing each protection claim on its own merits, on a case-by-case basis, with reference to up-to-date information on conditions in the applicant's home country. Principles of procedural fairness apply at all stages of visa decision making. Persons who have been found not to engage Australia's protection obligations have access, as permitted by the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), to merits review of that decision, and to seek judicial review in the courts.
4. With regard to the request to refuse to deport people to dangerous or life threatening situations:

The Australian Government is committed to its non-refoulement (non-return) obligations. As enshrined in the Act, Australia does not remove individuals to situations where they face real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the death penalty. Mechanisms which enable the Government to address non-refoulement obligations include:
- consideration of whether the applicant meets the definition of a refugee or the complementary protection criteria under the Act as part of the protection visa process,

- consideration of the use of the Minister's personal powers under the Act to intervene in a case when the Minister thinks it is in the public interest to do so; and consideration of whether Australia's non-refoulement obligations are engaged, as part of the pre-removal clearance for persons on a removal pathway.
5. With regard to the request to replace temporary protection visas with permanent protection visas:

Temporary protection visas enable the Australian Government to provide protection to unlawful arrivals who are found to engage Australia's non-refoulement obligations, without compromising its border security or the principles underpinning its humanitarian program.

Unlawful air arrivals and individuals from the Illegal Maritime Arrivals legacy caseload who engage Australia's protection obligations are only eligible for temporary protection (that is either a Temporary Protection visa or a Safe Haven Enterprise visa). If holders of Safe Haven Enterprise visas work without accessing certain social security benefits and/or study in a specified regional area for a period totally 42 months, they become eligible to apply for certain visas, including prescribed permanent visas.
Thank you for bringing the petition to the Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
from Malcolm McAllister, Assistant Secretary, Immigration and Settlement Services Group, Department of Home Affairs
Taxation
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2018 regarding PN0239, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding the taxation of minors' income from investments. As the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for response. The delay in response is regretted.

Minors in Australia are taxed according to the nature of the income they receive. All salary or wage income earned by minors is subject to ordinary rates of personal income tax, including the tax free threshold of $18,200. This recognises that the minor has earned this income through their own personal exertion.

The income of a minor earned through interest, dividends, royalties, rent and other income from property is referred to as 'unearned income'. Unearned income over $416 per annum is taxed at higher rates while unearned income up to $416 is taxed at ordinary resident rates in the normal way. These rules were first introduced in 1979 as an anti-avoidance measure to discourage adults from gaining a tax advantage by diverting income to their children so that it could be taxed at lower marginal rates.

The Government considers the current treatment of the unearned income of minors to be appropriate. These rules do not prevent money being invested for a minor and provided to them once they turn 18. For example, an adult could invest the money themselves and provide the money to the minor once the minor turns 18. Alternatively, the minor could invest in assets that do not result in a tax liability until they turn 18.

For example, as superannuation accounts can be opened for children, parents could assist their children to save for a home deposit through the First Home Super Saver Scheme (FHSSS) by giving their children money that the children then contribute to their superannuation accounts. The FHSSS, announced in the 2017-18 Budget, will help first home buyers to save a deposit through voluntary superannuation contributions.

From 1 July 2017, individuals can make voluntary contributions of up to $15,000 per year and $30,000 in total, to their superannuation account to purchase a first home. These contributions along with deemed earnings, can be withdrawn from 1 July 2018.

In superannuation, both earnings and concessional contributions from pre-tax earnings are taxed at 15 per cent. When a FHSSS withdrawal is made for a first home deposit, the amount is taxed at marginal tax rates less a 30 per cent offset. Individuals can also make non-concessional contributions under the FHSSS. No tax is paid on non-concessional amounts when they are contributed to a superannuation account or withdrawn under the FHSSS.

Contributions to the FHSSS made on behalf of children would generally be non-concessional in nature, as only children with taxable income would be able to claim a tax deduction and make the contribution concessional. The earnings in the child's superannuation account would be taxed at only 15 per cent. Contributions of up to $30,000 and associated deemed earnings could be released after the child turns 18. After a withdrawal is made from the FHSSS, an individual has 12 months, extendable up to 24 months, to purchase their first home.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer the Hon. Stuart Robert MP
Community Early Years Centre
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for bringing Petition PN0394 to my attention in your capacity as Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions. This petition relates to the closure of seven child care centres in the Albury-Wodonga region of New South Wales and Victoria in December 2018. The petitioners requested the House bring forward a bill to provide additional funding for rural child care facilities to help support rural families to access child care.

The Australian Government is investing record funding of $8.6 billion in 2019-20 into child care to provide more support for families. This investment will increase over the next few years to around $10 billion a year.

The Government's child care assistance provides targeted child care support for working families, a generous safety net to protect those most vulnerable in our community, and ongoing support for high quality early learning.

This Government recognises the unique challenges child care services face in regional and remote areas, such as low numbers of children, and attracting and retaining qualified staff. Families and services in regional and remote areas particularly benefit from funding under the Community Child Care Fund (CCCF). In regional and remote communities, the CCCF supports more than 480 services, which have been allocated $224 million over five years.

In relation to the sites referenced by the petitioners, I am pleased to inform the committee that child care services re-opened in six communities where an ongoing need was confirmed, including Bellbridge. These services opened during January 2019 and

February 2019. This quick response was largely thanks to a collaborative effort with community members, local providers, and State and Commonwealth governments. For the remaining site, the local Council advised there is no need for a child care service due to the availability of alternative arrangements.

The Government's response to the closure ofthese sites demonstrates the flexibility and capacity of the new child care system to respond to the child care needs of rural communities. The availability of CCCF Special Circumstance funding, under the Child Care Safety Net, supported new providers to take over the operation of the affected child care services in preparation for the new school year. Ongoing access to CCCF funds will support the longer-term sustainability of these child care services.

The Bellbridge Early Years Learning Centre, specifically mentioned by the petitioners, is currently operating with a combination of Child Care Subsidy income and CCCF Special Circumstance funding. They have recently submitted an application for CCCF funding and are expected to transfer to this long-term grant arrangement in September 2019.
I note EN0796 is a duplicate of PN0394.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education the Hon. Dan Tehan MP
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 February 2019 concerning petition number PN0397, which was presented in the House of Representatives, regarding the Australian Government's regional processing and resettlement arrangements and the Home Affairs Legislation Amendment (Miscellaneous Measures) Act 2019.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea. The success of Australia's border protection policies has also enabled the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing the global humanitarian crisis and increase our Humanitarian Program annual quota to 18,750 places, the highest since the 1950s.

The health and welfare of individuals in regional processing countries is of paramount importance to the governments of Australia, Nauru and Papua New Guinea (PNG). Individuals receive a range of services to support their stay in Nauru or PNG, including health and welfare, accommodation (rent and utility free), education and employment opportunities.

No individual under regional processing arrangements in Nauru or PNG is detained. All individuals reside in open living arrangements in the community, and are free to move around without restriction. Regional processing arrangements maintain the dignity and human rights of people without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.

Australia continues to support the Governments of Nauru and PNG to reduce the residual regional processing caseload through resettlement, returns and removals. Under current regional processing arrangements, refugees have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled. People found to be refugees by the Government of PNG can settle in PNG, while people found to be refugees by the Government of Nauru can stay in Nauru for 20 years.

Australia appreciates the offer from the New Zealand Government to resettle refugees, but we are focused on completing the arrangement with the United States. Australia's border protection policies have removed the incentive for people to join dangerous and illegal people smuggling ventures to Australia. The Australian Government remains mindful of not un-doing efforts to combat people smuggling.

Individuals in regional processing countries have access to quality health care. Medical services are provided by a range of healthcare professionals, including general practitioners, psychiatrists, counsellors, and mental health nurses who provide clinical assessment and treatment.
Where specialist medical treatment is not available in a regional processing country, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfers to a third country, including Australia, for treatment.
The Home Affairs Legislation Amendment (Miscellaneous Measures) Act 2019 came into effect on 2 March 2019 and legislates a medical transfer pathway to Australia for transitory persons.

The Australian Government has re-opened Christmas Island immigration detention facilities to manage transitory persons transferring from a regional processing country to Australia for medical purposes. Medical and support services on Christmas Island will be enhanced to cater for the health needs of those people transferred from Nauru and PNG.

Medical transfer to Australia is not a pathway to settlement in Australia. Persons brought to Christmas Island for medical treatment will not be permitted to remain in Australia permanently. Persons can depart Australia for their home country or resettle in a third country.

Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol. Regional processing arrangements provide asylum seekers an opportunity to have their protection claims assessed, and for those found to be refugees, resettlement in a third country, without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs the Hon. David Coleman MP
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Brien

I refer to correspondence of 5 April 2019 from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, concerning petition PN0402. The correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.
As a party to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and its

1967 Protocol (the Refugee Convention), Australia takes its international obligations seriously. Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the Refugee Convention and other relevant international treaties to which Australia is a party.

Anyone who comes to Australia illegally by boat will be intercepted and returned to their point of departure or their home country, or else transferred to a regional processing country for their protection claims to be considered by that country.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Australian Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.

The success of Australia's border protection policies has also enabled the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing the global humanitarian crisis and increase our Humanitarian Program annual quota to 18,750 places, which represents the largest ongoing program in over 30 years.

People transferred and accommodated under regional processing arrangements are treated with respect and dignity and in accordance with human rights standards. The Government has contracted appropriately trained and experienced service providers to support the host country governments to ensure that refugee and asylum seekers' needs are adequately met, including the provision of health and welfare services.

Regional processing arrangements in Papua New Guinea (PNG) and the individuals under those arrangements are the responsibility of the Government of PNG. Refugees and transferees in PNG are not subject to detention and are free to move about the community.

The Government continues to support the Government of PNG to reduce the residual regional processing caseload through resettlement, returns and removals. Under current regional processing arrangements, refugees have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled.

People found to be refugees by the Government of PNG can settle in PNG, seek assisted voluntary return or move to a country they have the right to reside in. In addition to this, a one-off arrangement with the United States to support the resettlement of refugees from PNG is in place and is progressing.
Australia continues to explore alternative resettlement options for refugees under regional processing settings.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs the Hon. Peter Dutton MP

from the Minister for Home Affairs the Hon. Peter Dutton MP
Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration
Dear Chair
I refer to your letters of 5 April concerning Petitions PN0405 and PN0407 for the cure of pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN). I regret the delay in responding.

1 acknowledge the debilitating effects PKAN has and can understand the desire for clinical trials of potential treatments to be undertaken as soon as possible. It is encouraging to hear about CoA-Z as a potential treatment for PKAN.

My office has contacted Dr Susan Hayflick of NBIAcure and provided the following background about how medicines and clinical trials are regulated in Australia and the potential opportunities offered by the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) Rare Cancers, Rare Diseases and Unmet Need (RCRDUN) Grant Opportunity for conducting clinical trials in Australia.

As you may be aware, medicines imported into, supplied in, and exported from Australia must be entered in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG), which is administered by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). To be included in the ARTG a sponsor is required to make an application with evidence to support its safety, quality and effectiveness. The Australian Government is unable to compel a sponsor to make an application to the TGA, although a future application for CoA-Z would be welcomed.

In recognition that there may be circumstances where 'unapproved' medicines, like CoA-Z, are required by patients in Australia, there are a number of ways in which doctors may be able to access them for their patients, including in clinical trials.

The Australian Government aims to increase clinical trial activity in Australia by supporting new, high quality research. The MRFF provides funding to priority health and medical research and in particular, the RCRDUN initiative encourages the application of novel and innovative clinical trial methodologies, such as the application of precision medicine to take individual genetic variation into account in disease treatment.

In the 2019-20 Budget, the Australian Government announced an extension of the clinical trials activity initiative with $614 million now available over the next 10 years. The MRFF is currently supporting 48 clinical trials with a collective total value of $75 million. The next RCRDUN grant opportunity is expected to open shortly and I expect many researcher teams will be preparing applications to access the $50 million available in 2019-20. For further details about the grant opportunity see www.nhmrc.gov.au and use the search term 'MRFF Rare Cancers, Rare Diseases and Unmet Need Grant Opportunity'.

The TGA does not itself conduct clinical trials but does have a role in the administration of clinical trials in Australia. The Clinical Trial Notification scheme requires that all material relating to the proposed trial, including the trial protocol, be submitted to a Human Research Ethics Committee by the researcher. The sponsor of the medicine must then notify the TGA of a clinical trial being conducted. Importantly, the TGA does not review any data relating to the clinical trial and is unable to compel a sponsor of a medicine to run a clinical trial.

Outside of clinical trials, the TGA administers the Special Access Scheme (SAS) to enable access to 'unapproved' therapeutic goods for individual patients on a case-by-case basis. In life-threatening cases, the SAS Category A notification pathway is available to authorise the supply of an 'unapproved' medicine to a single patient. Should CoA-Z become available overseas, a doctor could consider the use of SAS to access it for Australian patients.
Further information on the SAS, including the forms that would need to be completed by a medical practitioner, can be found at www.tga.gov.au/form/special-access-scheme.
Thank you for bringing this issue to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service and Cabinet the Hon. Greg Hunt MP
Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Radio National
Dear Mr O'Brien

I refer to the letter of 5 April 2019 from Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, to the former to Senator the Hon Mitch Fifield about petition PN0408 concerning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

While the Australian Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC, the ABC has legislated independence in relation to operational matters. Parliament has guaranteed this independence and as a consequence, internal ABC operational decisions such as these are the responsibility of the ABC Board and Executive.

In 2019-20 the Government will provide the ABC over $1 billion in annual funding. This represents a substantial investment of public funds and will ensure that the ABC is able to continue to provide television, radio and digital media services in line with its Charter. The ABC has greater funding certainty than any other media organisation in the nation.

The ABC advises that the power output of the 720AM Annidale Radio National (RN) service is limited by the capacity of the transmitter infrastructure at the site and also potential interference to other radio broadcasts. The alternative provision of an FM Armidale Radio National service would be based on available FM spectrum in the region. In addition, FM services already in Armidale (101.1FM triple j, 101.9FM Local Radio, 102.7FM NewsRadio and 103.5FM Classic FM) already only have comparable coverage to the 720AM RN service. RN is available in the broader region on 100.7FM to the west of Armidale and on 99.5FM towards the coast.

Furthermore, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has advised that power limits and potential interference is due to the proximity of the Murwillumbah/Tweed Heads ABC local radio service 2ML. While there may be scope to increase the power of the Armidale RN service if changed to an FM frequency, it would require infrastructure upgrades and planning approval, which is complex and often lengthy.

Your petitioners may be interested to know that the ACMA is currently reviewing a proposal for the Annidale AM commercial radio service 2AD to convert to FM and expects to consult on a variation to the licence area plan later this year. I would suggest that your petitioners contact the ACMA to determine if additional FM frequencies could be used for the Armidale RN service.

The petitioners can raise their concerns directly with the ABC, by writing to Audience and Consumer Affairs, GPO Box 9994, in their capital city, or by lodging a complaint at www.abc.net.au/contact/complain.htm. This will ensure that the ABC is directly aware of their concerns and has an opportunity to respond to them. The ACMA can be contacted by email at info@acma.gov.au or telephone on 1300 850 115.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts the Hon. Paul Fletcher MP
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

I refer to the letter of 4 April 2019 from the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks. to the former Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation, Senator the Hon Bridget McKenzie, regarding Petition PN0409 to address mobile coverage issues in Violet Town and District, Victoria. I am responding as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I note the petitioner's concern that residents in Violet Town and District are receiving intermittent and unreliable mobile phone coverage. The predictive coverage maps published by the major carriers indicate that Violet Town should be receiving good levels of 4G indoor and outdoor coverage, although there are some areas to the south and southeast of Boho and to the northwest at Tamleugh which may receive little to no coverage.

However, even in areas of good coverage there are a number of factors that can interfere with mobile reception and therefore impact a user's ability to obtain or maintain a mobile phone signal at any given time or place. These factors include hilly terrain, buildings (including their internal structure) or other physical obstacles such as trees interrupting the line-of-sight from the nearest mobile base station. In this instance, the hilly terrain south of Violet Town may impact the level of coverage received by residents in this area to the south and southeast of the town itself.

While mobile carriers claim to provide coverage to 99 per cent of Australia's population, there are still many parts of Australia where there is no coverage, particularly in regional and remote locations. The Australian Government is committed to delivering the clear economic, social and public safety benefits of expanded mobile coverage for people living, working and travelling in regional and remote areas of Australia.

This is why the Government has announced a further $160 million in two new funding rounds (Rounds 5 and 6) of the Program in response to the 2018 Regional Telecommunications Review. This additional funding takes the Government's total commitment to address mobile black spots across Australia to $380 million.

Round 5 of the Program will have a strong focus on further improving mobile coverage in our regions. including at Public Interest Premises which benefit the community such as medical facilities, schools and economic centres. The Government has allocated $80 million to Round 5 of the Program and we are in the process of seeking Round 5 applications from the mobile industry. Applications are due by 26 September 2019.

As part of the application process, registered applicants will be provided with the National Mobile Black Spot Database to assist them to identify possible locations for funding. I note that Violet Town is listed on the Database as a black spot location. However, please note that locations do not need to be registered in the Database to receive funding under the Program.

Communities are encouraged to liaise directly with mobile network operators. local councils, and federal and state parliamentary representatives to nominate priority black spots in the region and seek their co-contributions for Round 5. I would therefore encourage the petitioner and other residents to contact the carriers to make their coverage issues known and to identify ways of maximising their mobile phone reception. including the potential for an application for funding under Round 5. 1 have enclosed the contact details of the carriers for reference.
Contact: Ms Loretta Willaton
Position: Regional General Manager
Telstra Eastern Victoria
Telephone no: 132 200
Email: TelstraEastVicateam.telstra.com
Website: www.telstra.com.au/coverage-networks/mobile-black-spot-program
Telephone no: 133 937
Email: mobileblackspotprogramme@optus.com.au
Website: www.optus.net.au/shop/mobile/networkimobile-black-spot-program
Telephone no: 1300 302 703
Email: communityrelations@vodafone.com.au
Website: www.vodafone.com.au

There are also a number of products that can improve mobile reception including the use of an external antenna or in-car-kit if travelling on regional roads. The particular handset used can also affect mobile reception, and some compatible handsets now allow customers to call and text over a Wi-Fi connection. The most appropriate solution may depend upon the network, and prices can vary. Customers can obtain accessories and advice on the best solution for local conditions by contacting their service provider or visiting their nearest mobile phone shop or recognised dealer.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Services, Decentralisation and Local Government the Hon. Mark Coulton MP
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
I refer to the letter dated 5 April 2019 from the former Chair of the Standing Committee.

Mrs Lucy Wicks MP. to the former Minister for Communications and the Arts. Senator the Hon Mitch Fifield. concerning a petition (PN0410) requesting that the Australian Government address mobile coverage and satellite-only free-to-air television and National Broadband Network services in Bicheno. Tasmania. This letter has been referred to me for reply as I have portfolio responsibility for the matters raised as Minister for Regional Services, Decentralisation and Local Government.

I note the concerns of the residents of Rosedale and Ferndale Roads and Suncoast Drive. Bicheno, regarding the lack of mobile coverage in their area. The coverage maps published by the major carriers (Telstra. Optus and Vodafone) confirm that these addresses should be receiving varying levels of 3G coverage, with some areas receiving no coverage at all, particularly under the Telstra network.

Even in areas of good coverage there are a number of factors that can interfere with mobile reception and therefore impact a user's ability to obtain or maintain a mobile phone signal at any given time or place. These factors include hilly terrain. buildings (including their internal structure) or other physical obstacles such as trees interrupting the line-of-sight from the nearest mobile base station. In this instance, areas of hilly terrain and dense bushland between the Rosedale Road area and the nearest base station 5.3 km away in Bicheno, which was funded under round 1 of the Program, are likely to reduce the amount of coverage received by residents.

The Government is committed to delivering the clear economic, social and public safety benefits of expanded mobile coverage for people living, working and travelling in regional and remote areas of Australia. This is why the Government has announced a further $160 million in two new funding rounds (Rounds 5 and 6) of the Program in response to the 2018 Regional Telecommunications Review. This additional funding takes the Government's total commitment to address mobile black spots across Australia to $380 million.

The Government has allocated $80 million to Round 5 of the Program. Round 5 will have a strong focus on further improving mobile coverage in our regions, including at Public Interest Premises which benefit the community such as medical facilities. schools and economic centres. Applications for Round 5 are currently being sought from the mobile industry, and close on 26 September 2019. As part of the application process, registered applicants will be provided with the National Mobile Black Spot Database which was recently updated during Round 4. This will assist them to identify possible locations for funding, however it is important to note that locations do not need to be registered in the Database to receive funding under the Program.

Communities are encouraged to liaise directly with mobile network operators. local councils. and Federal Members to nominate priority black spots in the region and seek co-contributions for Round 5 of the Program. Consideration in the assessment process is given to the cost to the Commonwealth of a base station, and therefore the amount of co-contribution, if any, the MNO has secured from a third party such as a state or local government is important.

I would encourage residents in the Rosedale Road area to make further representations to the major carriers to identify ways of maximising their mobile phone reception and to discuss a potential application for funding under Round 5. 1 have enclosed the details of the major carriers for reference.
Contact: Michael Patterson
Position: Regional General Manager Tasmania
Telephone: 13 22 20
Email address: TelstraTas@team.telstra.com
Website: www.telstra.com.au/coverage-networks/mobile-black-spot-program
Customer Service: 133 937
Email: mobileblackspotprogramme@optus.com.au
Website: www.optus.net.au
Customer Service: 1300 302 703
Email: communityrelations@vodafone.com.au
Website: www.vodafone.com.au

There are also a number of products that can improve mobile reception including the use of an external antenna or in-car-kit if travelling on regional roads. For example, Telstra has released a 'Smart Antenna' to improve indoor reception on its network and Wi-Fi calling is available on the mobile carriers' networks for use with a compatible device allowing some customers to call and text over a Wi-Fi connection. The particular handset used can also affect mobile reception.

The most appropriate solution may depend on the network, and prices can vary. Customers can obtain accessories and advice on the best solution by contacting their service provider or visiting their nearest mobile phone shop or recognised dealer.

I also note residents' concerns regarding the lack of terrestrial television services in their area. The Viewer Access Satellite Television (VAST) service was established in 2010 as part of the switchover to digital television to ensure that all Australian households would be able to access a comprehensive range of standard and high definition digital free-to-air television services. The VAST platform also supports the transmission of radio services.

The VAST service includes the full suite of ABC and SBS digital television services. The ABCI service is provided on an individual state and territory basis. In Eastern Australia, the commercial free-to-air channels available on VAST are provided by Imparja Television and Southern Cross Austere°, drawing on content from the Seven, Nine and Ten networks. The VAST service also includes dedicated news channels carrying nightly bulletins from regional commercial television broadcasters. For example, WIN News (ch409) and 7 Nightly News (ch4l 1) provide regional news for Tasmania.
Residents in Bicheno may find local content relevant to them on this website www.sattvguide.com.au and further information on VAST channels and zones can be found on the Information page.

There are no subscription fees or other ongoing costs for VAST. However, viewers require satellite reception equipment (a roof-top dish) and an authorised VAST set-top box. Access to the commercial channels on VAST is limited by a smart card system managed by the commercial broadcasters and overseen by the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA). As with terrestrial television, viewers are responsible for the costs of reception equipment and installation. Information on how to gain access to VAST is available from the VAST Administration Centre on 1300 993 376 or online (www.mysattv.com.au).

On 3 January 2019 the Government published a review of the VAST service, which recommended that the current satellite delivery model should be continued. The review examined all available options, compared to satellite delivery arrangements, and found that no viable alternative is available now or in the near future that offers equivalent or improved service delivery. The VAST review received 33 submissions and the Department engaged with 19 stakeholder organisations during the review process. Stakeholders included regional broadcasters, satellite providers, consumer groups and individual VAST users.
In response to the review, the Government has extended the current funding of the VAST service to 30 June 2021.

With respect to issues residents raised concerning the NBN satellite service, the Department raised the matter with NBN Co Limited on their behalf. NBN Co confirmed its satellite service is working to specification and that the company is not aware of any uncharacteristic issues affecting its services in the area. In all cases, if a customer is dissatisfied with their NBN service, they should lodge a complaint with their retail service provider to investigate. RSPs are responsible for providing NBN services to their customers and will work with NBN Co to resolve any issue that is related to the NAN.

The Australian Government is spending around $2 billion to design, build and operate two technologically-advanced satellites. NBN Co's satellite broadband service offers consumers access to download speeds of up to 25 Mbps and upload speeds of up to 5 Mbps. These speeds are more than sufficient to run a variety of popular internet applications such as web browsing, emailing and video streaming.

The NBN Co satellite service is not a 'set and forget' network, and the company is continually looking into service upgrades. For instance, in July 2019, NBN Co will launch its enhanced 'Sky Muster Plus' product which may be of interest to local residents. The product will enable consumers to access unmetered data for web browsing, email and software updates on their computers and phones. More information on the product can be found on NBN Co's website at www.nbnco.com.au.
It is important to note that NBN Co is building and operating the NBN on a commercial basis at arm's length from Government in line with the Statement of Expectations, which is available at
www.nbnco.com.au/content/dam/nbnco2/documents/soe-shareholde-minister-letter.pdf.
Accordingly, network technology selection and day to day operational issues are matters for the company.

NBN Co determines which technologies are most cost-effective and should be utilised on an area-by-area basis to minimise peak funding, optimise economic returns. and deliver broadband upgrades sooner. The company has revised the technology mix in some areas to ensure it is able to offer services to all Australians as quickly and affordably as possible.
Ubiquitous. fast broadband has the potential to unlock greater innovation and productivity across all sectors of the economy which makes timely completion of the network so crucial.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Services, Decentralisation and Local Government the Hon. Mark Coulton MP
PETITIONS
Statements

Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:02): The committee is heartened by the large volume of responses to petitions it has received. Many of these respond to petitions presented in the 45th Parliament. The committee will monitor the rate of responses received as the parliament progresses. The committee thanks the ministers concerned for their cooperation. Historically, responses to petitions to the House were rare. Now the Petitions Committee refers the majority of petitions to a relevant minister, and most are responded to. Once presented, a response is forwarded to the person who created the petition, and a copy is made available on the House petitions website.

The response process is a feature of petitioning the House that sets it apart from other petitioning platforms. The process offers a public conversation between the petitioner and the government, facilitated by the House. On behalf of the Petitions Committee, I commend the petitioning process to other members and encourage all Australians to get involved in petitioning the parliament. I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the Petitions Committee.
BILLS
Australian Bill of Rights Bill 2019
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Wilkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr WILKIE (Clark) (10:04): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Bill of Rights Bill 2019 would enshrine the fundamental rights of all Australians in Australian law. It's modelled closely on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 2001, introduced by the then member for Calwell, and is very similar to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 2017, which I introduced.

In essence, the bill would render invalid any Commonwealth, state or territory law that's inconsistent with the Bill of Rights to the extent of that inconsistency. It would also specify that Commonwealth, state and territory laws should be interpreted so as to be consistent with the bill of rights.

The bill allows for the Australian Human Rights Commission to inquire into any act or practice done by the Commonwealth or a state or territory government that may infringe on a right or freedom in the bill of rights. It also allows for people to make complaints to the commission if they believe that an act or practice infringes a right or freedom outlined in this bill.

The bill would also give effect to a number of international agreements to which Australia is a signatory, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Cultural and Social Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

The importance of this bill is self-evident. We are the only democratic nation without any sort of bill or charter of rights. What domestic legislation we do have is scarce and far too narrow. Indeed, there are only five relevant acts in this country that attempt to protect human rights—the Human Rights Commission Act, which is really just about regulating the commission, the Racial Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act, the Age Discrimination act and the Disability Discrimination Act.

Yes, the government is intending to add to this flimsy framework by introducing a religious discrimination bill. But, perversely, such legislation would in fact further restrict human rights in this country, which begs the question: why introduce a piece of legislation that promotes special rights for particular groups of people rather than supporting a piece of legislation that will promote the rights of all Australians?

Moreover—and regrettably—the parliamentary processes with regard to human rights are also flimsy and weak. For instance, the committees of the House of Representatives are invariably beholden to the government because of the numbers, and Senate committees are generally ignored by the government because they are, more often than not, controlled by the opposition or by the crossbench. As a result, the international agreements and obligations Australia has committed to, which one would think would provide protection to Australians, are in fact routinely ignored.
In other words, the only effective way to protect the rights of all Australians is to establish a single, strong and reliable framework as described in my bill today.

This isn't a new concept in Australia, as evidenced by the ACT, Victoria and Queensland who have all taken positive steps by introducing human rights legislation. But, understandably, these state based frameworks simply aren't good enough on their own and we still need a consistent national approach that will enshrine the rights and freedoms of all Australians regardless of where they live. The bottom line is that we still need a national bill of rights that protects and promotes unalienable human rights such as the right to health care, the right to housing, the right to education and the right to equal treatment within society.

To those who ask 'Where's the proof that we are in need of a bill of rights in the first place?' I say you only need to look at what is happening in our country in recent times—in particular, the blatant disregard for an ignorance of international agreements to which Australia is a party. And nowhere is this clearer than when we look at the government's response to asylum seekers and refugees, the attacks on press freedom and the unprecedented difficulties in accessing fundamental services such as housing and health care. None of this should be happening in Australia, and it only does so because we don't have an overarching framework to protect our rights.

The appalling raids by the Australian Federal Police on the ABC and on journalists are a perfect example. Surely it is unthinkable that in a supposedly free and democratic country like Australia the government's police force is raiding media organisations and trying to suppress freedom of the press. That demonstrates why article 4 of this Bill of Rights is important to enshrine a right to freedom of expression and freedom of the press.

We also need a bill of rights because of the appalling way Indigenous people are treated in this country. I don't need to list all of the statistics about things like incarceration rates—we've heard them all before—but it is patently obvious that many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aren't being afforded their basic human rights. Article 10 of this bill, though, would specifically enshrine the rights of Indigenous peoples—as well as many other sections of the bill that would help improve the lives of Indigenous Australians.

And what about the atrociously high rates of homelessness in this country? Nowhere is this more apparent than in my home state of Tasmania, where the housing waiting lists have soared and the state government seems to think doing nothing is the best policy. Article 23 of this bill would enshrine a right to an adequate standard of living, including clothing and housing.

In closing I would just like to say that when I first tabled this bill, in 2017, the response from the community was overwhelmingly positive. Some people couldn't believe we didn't already have a bill of rights. Others knew that it was about time to introduce one. But, despite all of that, neither the government nor the opposition supported the bill, in what was another striking example of their failure to represent the community. So today I urge both the Liberal and Labor parties to reconsider their stubborn opposition, and to wake up and to realise that we need to stop lagging behind the rest of the world and to stop allowing our rights and freedoms to be eroded.
In my remaining time, I invite the member for Mayo to add a few comments.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (10:10): I'm delighted to second this motion.
The SPEAKER: The member for Mayo may proceed.

Ms SHARKIE: Australia is the only Western democracy that does not have a bill of human rights. Instead, we have a patchwork of state and federal legislation from which we construct and construe a series of implied and express freedoms. Our Constitution provides for only five express rights: the right to vote, the right to a trial by jury, freedom of religion, protection against acquisition of property on unjust terms and a prohibition on the basis of state of residency.

There is an implied freedom of speech, but last month the High Court confirmed unanimously that Australians do not have a personal right to freedom of speech. In its ruling, the court upheld the government's right to sack Michaela Banerji, a public servant, for her anonymous critical tweets about the government's immigration policy. But we already knew our freedom of speech was on shaky ground, following the raids on Annika Smethurst, Ben Fordham and the ABC studio's journalists. Journalists must now be reticent in talking with whistleblowers. We cannot let that become Australia. That must not be. We must have journalists who have the courage to be able to talk to whistleblowers for the benefit of all of us, for the rights and freedoms of all of us. As Bernard Collaery and Witness K will attest to, we can forgo any rights in the face of national security concerns. Richard Boyle, an ATO officer, questioned the behaviour of the ATO, and is currently facing trial.

A bill of rights would remind the government of the day that any intrusion into our civil liberties must be reasonable and proportionate to achieve a legitimate end, and it would equip the courts with the laws they need to ensure that a just outcome is reached. Again, we are the only Western democracy that does not have a bill or charter of rights, and we need to fix this.

The SPEAKER: The question is that this bill be now read a second time. The time allotted for this debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: Fair Work Amendment (Stop Work to Stop Warming) Bill 2019

p.span: Fair Work Amendment (Stop Work to Stop Warming) Bill 2019
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Bandt.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading

Mr BANDT (Melbourne) (10:14): Any boss who sacks anyone for not turning up to work on Friday is a bum. This Friday millions of people across the world will walk out of their classrooms, workplaces and homes in a global climate strike. People are striking because, after 30 years of failure by governments around the world, pollution is continuing to rise and the extreme impacts of the climate crisis are becoming worse. People are striking because we're in a climate emergency, and if governments continue in their failure to act then there will be disruption of business as usual. Students have led the way, and this time they're asking workers to join them. We hope that they will.

The Arctic is on fire. The Greenland ice sheet is melting at a record rate. The Amazon is burning. Heatwaves are sweeping the planet. The monster storm of Hurricane Dorian, fuelled by the heat of the ocean, wiped out much of the Bahamas. Here in Australia, the Bureau of Meteorology says we're seeing the most severe drought on record in the Murray-Darling Basin, our country's food bowl. We're just out of winter, and hundreds of fires have already ravaged the east of Australia, including wet Queensland rainforest that does not usually burn, repeating the experience of fires in Tasmania that burnt forests that haven't seen these kinds of extreme fires before. Now we're told that our towns may well be running out of water in the very near future.

Beyond these immediate impacts is the frightening reality that, as the permafrost in the Arctic thaws and the world's forests burn, the carbon released will create further global warming. This is just the beginning of cascading extreme impacts and dangerous feedback that threaten millions of species with extinction and threaten human civilisation. Eminent scientists have warned us that the carrying capacity of our planet is less than a billion people if global warming is allowed to reach four degrees. We're at 7½ at the moment. That's 7½ down to one billion people. This means that billions of lives will be lost to mass starvation, disease, dislocation and conflict. I repeat: billions of lives will be lost. Yet, despite this looming catastrophe, we also know that the current pollution reduction commitments made by governments of the world, including Australia, under the Paris agreement have us on track for 3½ to four degrees of global warming. Again, that is worth repeating. We've signed up to keeping global warming to below two degrees, and ideally 1½, but the current climate rescue plan has us on track for 3½ to four degrees of global warming, which will lead to global warming that is a death sentence for billions of people on the planet.

This is why people around the world are rebelling. It's why we're seeing the rise of mass non-violent civil disobedience led by groups such as Extinction Rebellion, who blockaded Melbourne's Princes Bridge on the weekend. It's why, since a year ago, many millions of school students around the world have joined school strikes each Friday, inspired by Swedish student Greta Thunberg, and it's why millions of people will join the students by striking this Friday. I want to read an excerpt from the call to action for this Friday's global strike, signed by Greta Thunberg, among many others:

Starting on Friday 20 September we will kickstart a week of climate action with a worldwide strike for the climate. We're asking adults to step up alongside us. There are many different plans under way in different parts of the world for adults to join together and step up and out of your comfort zone for our climate. Let's all join together, with your neighbours, co-workers, friends, family and go out on to the streets to make your voices heard and make this a turning point in our history.

This is about crossing lines—it's about rebelling wherever one can rebel. It's not about saying "Yeah, what the kids do is great, if I was young I would have totally joined in." It doesn’t help, but everyone can and must help.

During the French revolution mothers flooded the streets for their children. Today we children are fighting for ourselves, but so many of our parents are busy discussing whether our grades are good, or a new diet or what happened in the Game of Thrones finale—while the planet burns.

This moment has to happen. Last year's UN intergovernmental panel on climate change's special report on global warming was clear about the unprecedented dangers of going beyond 1.5C of global heating. Emissions must drop rapidly—so that by the time we are in our mid- and late-20s we are living in a completely transformed world.

But to change everything, we need everyone. It is time for all of us to unleash mass resistance—we have shown that collective action does work. We need to escalate the pressure to make sure that change happens, and we must escalate together.

So this is our chance—join us on climate strike this September. People have risen up before to demand action and make change; if we do so in numbers we have a chance. If we care, we must do more than say we do. We must act. This won't be the last day we need to take to the streets, but it will be a new beginning. We're counting on you.
That's the end of the statement from the student strikers.

This is the beginning of an uprising that will alone grow if governments fail to tell the truth about the climate crisis and fail to take emergency action. Students have asked workers to join them this Friday. Workers in Australia currently enjoy constitutionally protected rights to engage in political speech, including political protest, and I would argue strongly that that includes protest about global warming and government policies needed to tackle it. In other words, people have a constitutional right to take Friday off work to protest, and I hope that many do. There are also many workers who've been encouraged by their employers to attend and, if you're lucky enough to work in one of the many businesses supporting the strike action, such as Michael Cannon-Brookes's Atlassian software company, then you know there's absolutely no problem in turning up to the strike.

However, the need to tackle global warming is only going to get more pressing and there will be more and more actions and demonstrations. The Greens think the time has come to make the law crystal clear so that people know where they stand. After all, the Fair Work Act has many provisions that restrict industrial action, in breach of international law, and it would be disappointing if some employers used these provisions to try to take away peoples' rights to take part in climate change action. Global warming is a threat to the interests and wellbeing of the entire Australian population, including workers, so workers who engage in industrial action to push for a response to the climate emergency should be explicitly protected under the Fair Work Act. Workers and employers should also have the right to bargain about climate change related matters, given how important and pervasive this issue is.

That's why today I'm introducing the Fair Work Amendment (Stop Work to Stop Warming) Bill 2019. This bill puts beyond doubt that employees covered by the Fair Work Act 2009 have a right to take industrial action for the purpose of demanding that action be taken to address climate change. It also clarifies that employees and employers may bargain and agree about climate change matters. The bill does this through two primary means. Firstly, the bill introduces a new category of protected climate change industrial action. In lay terms, this means that taking time off work for the purpose of demanding that action be taken to address climate change is protected. Employees taking such action would be immune from having any action taken against them under any Australian law, provided that their action remains within certain limits, such as not being a threat to anyone else's life or safety. Secondly, the bill permits employees and employers to include in their enterprise agreements matters pertaining to climate change. This will also permit employees to take protected industrial action within the existing meaning of the act—action taken in support of securing the enterprise agreement—about such matters. Even the government, composed of the free-marketeers, should support that, because it allows employees and employers to bargain about these matters. The bill thus adds at the end of section 172(1) words that provide that an enterprise agreement is permitted to contain ' matters pertaining to climate change'. This is a broad definition which encompasses not only climate change related matters directly related to a particular enterprise, such as the use of renewable energy or the financial investments of the employer, but also matters relating to the effects of climate change, such as extreme heat or drought, as well as policy and government action of climate change, such as support for a particular emissions reduction target.

This Friday's global climate strike is just the beginning. We already know that our Prime Minister will boycott next week's UN Climate Action Summit, despite being in the United States, and that his government and many other governments around the world will fail to act with the urgency that is needed unless we force them to act. That is why strike action will continue to grow. It's very likely that many, many millions of Australians will join the actions over the next few years. I want those workers to know that, when they join such strikes or when they take industrial action to get their employer to implement changes to reduce global warming, this parliament has their back. I want them to know that the Fair Work Act provides them with the protection they need to push for strong action from governments and big business to solve the climate crisis. That's why I've moved this bill and why I commend this bill to the House.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wilkie: I second the motion moved by the member for Melbourne and reserve my right to speak.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019 [No. 2]

p.span: National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019 [No. 2]
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Sharkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (10:25): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Time is of the essence. During a debate in the Federation Chamber last week on the member for Oxley's motion on small amount credit contracts, the member for Higgins made a number of comments in defence of the government's failure to introduce legislation to combat predatory payday lending. The member for Higgins said the coalition government is:

… committed to restoring trust in our financial industry and to supporting low-income Australians … what this government is not is one that rushes in legislation without diligence, without consideration and without patience.

There is a difference between due diligence and delay. There is a difference between patience and pandering. The government are on the wrong side of the divide, and they know it. The member for Higgins went on to state:
Unintended consequences from poorly considered legislation can have profound implications on the most vulnerable members of our community.

How much time do we need? Do you know what else can have profound implications on the most vulnerable members of our community? Interest rates at 407 per cent! It has been over a thousand days since the government accepted the recommendations of the independent small-amount credit contract review,and it has been nearly two years since the government circulated its own exposure draft legislation based on recommendations it had already accepted. But the years have passed and the coalition government is yet to introduce the bill into parliament. There are enough other bills that have come in here, multiple times. This one sits on a shelf gathering dust.

My bill today, the National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019 [No. 2], replicates the government's own exposure draft legislation released in October 2017. As the government would be aware, the bill will improve consumer protections for those who use payday loans and consumer leases. Consistent with the government's exposure draft legislation, this bill will introduce a cap on the total payments that can be made under a consumer lease and requires small amount credit contracts to have equal repayments and equal payment intervals.

The bill will also remove the ability for SACC providers to charge monthly fees in respect of the residual term of a loan, where a consumer fully repays the loan early, and would prevent lessors and credit assistance providers from undertaking door-to-door selling of consumer leases at residential homes, which is predatory behaviour. Importantly, the bill would also introduce broad anti-avoidance protections to prevent SACC loan and consumer lease providers from circumventing the rules and protections contained in the credit act and the code, and strengthen penalties to increase incentives for SACC providers and lessors to comply with the law.

I note that, in the last parliament, the opposition signalled their intention to support the government's proposed legislation to reform both payday lending and the consumer lease framework. There has now been a clear signal from the opposition and some members of the crossbench that the government has the support it needs to achieve meaningful financial reforms. If only the government would act with the urgency that this issue clearly requires.

Just last month at the meeting of state and Commonwealth ministers for consumer affairs it was again agreed that urgent action is needed to address the harm caused by payday lending. But what do we have? We have nothing. There was no mention of the draft legislation or when, if ever, the government might decide to take it off the shelf, dust it off and finally introduce it into this place.

In question time last week I asked the Treasurer when the government planned to introduce legislation to protect vulnerable Australians from the harm caused by these financial products. The response? 'The Assistant Treasurer is working on this issue.' Unlike the Assistant Treasurer, however, the payday lending industry has been very busy. According to research carried out by Digital Finance Analytics, in the year since the release of the review in April 2016, three million new payday loans have been taken out. That's $1.85 billion in payday loans.

Stop the Debt Trap! is a coalition of over 20 consumer advocacy groups, including CHOICE, the Consumer Action Law Centre and the Salvation Army. The Salvation Army, in particular, sees people who are in an incredibly vulnerable situation and have multiple payday loans. They go to the Salvation Army for urgent assistance. These organisations have spent years at the coalface and they know that these harmful products can trap individuals in a crippling cycle of debt—a debt that can have far-reaching consequences for the individual and their family.

Earlier this year, the Senate inquiry into credit and financial services heard evidence that payday lenders were concentrating in areas of high unemployment, with large proportions of single-parent families and low gross income. These companies are targeting areas of social and economic disadvantage, and the current regulatory framework enables the exploitation of vulnerable Australians—and it must stop.

It is also important to clarify that these loans do not arise out of a fleeting desire for a flat screen TV or a quick trip to Bali but out of sheer desperation. They are low-income individuals. Many are facing a time of crisis such as family violence or unexpected illness. It may be that the car has broken down and they just need some money to replace tyres that have been defected or the engine to be fixed—things that are needed—particularly in regional areas where there is no alternative. There's no bus they can get on. They can't just park the car in the carport and say, 'That's okay; I'll save up and get that fixed.' They really have no alternative. It may be that the fridge breaks down or the hot water service goes. What do they do? They look for a short-term financial support. These are the low-income Australians that the member for Higgins referred to in her speech, and these are the consumers that the Treasurer says he wants to protect.

Nobody is seeking to eliminate small amount credit contracts. All that I and many members in this place want—and, importantly, what the public wants—and argue what the government has already accepted, is improved protections for people who use payday loans and consumer leases. I urge the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer to ignore the friends of payday lending, ignore the lobbyists who walk up and down these corridors saying, 'Leave it alone; everything is fine,' and finally introduce the bill into this place. Let's do some good work for vulnerable Australians. Let's learn from the royal commission, let's listen to the remarks of Commissioner Hayne and let's put people before profits. This would have a profound impact on the most vulnerable Australians. We need to act now.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Rob Mitchell ): I thank the member for Mayo. Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wilkie: I second the bill moved by the member for Mayo and reserve my right to speak.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER: I thank the member for Clark. The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Real Time Disclosure of Political Donations) Bill 2019

p.span: Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Real Time Disclosure of Political Donations) Bill 2019
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Sharkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (10:35): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

In December 2018, the Museum of Australian Democracy launched their Democracy 2025 initiative with a report entitled Trust and democracy in Australia: democratic decline andrenewal. The report found that if nothing is done to address the erosion of trust in key institutions fewer than 10 per cent of Australians—one in 10—will trust their politicians and political institutions by 2025. Trust is essential to effective government, as without trust we do not have the ability to address complex, long-term challenges, such as climate change, such as an aging population.

With fewer than 41 per cent of Australians—just two in five—currently satisfied with the way democracy works in Australia, we need to consider how to address the suspicion and dissatisfaction of the Australian public, politicians and political institutions. And there are steps that we as legislators can take now to arrest that decline—very simple steps, Mr Deputy Speaker.

The Democracy 2025 report highlights an issue that was common to every demographic, namely the influence of big business on politicians. Irrespective of age, gender or political persuasion there was very strong support for reforms that would insure greater integrity and transparency in political donations.

The Commonwealth framework for political donations is in need of reform. There are measures that can be made today that would significantly improve the disclose regime, such as implementing expenditure caps, significantly lowering the disclosure threshold below the current level of $13,800, aggregating donations and providing for real-time disclosure of donations.

But when presented with an opportunity to make any one of these meaningful reforms, as part of the debate around foreign donation laws last year, both the government and the opposition turned a blind eye. So, once again, it's up to the crossbench to shine a light on the activities of the major parties.

The bill I am introducing today focuses on just one area of electoral reform, namely real-time disclosure of donations. Currently, the Commonwealth government donations disclosure scheme provides for annual returns.
